Mediation Analysis: Understanding Indirect Effects

mediation-analysis.Rmd

üîÑ Mediation Analysis

Mediation analysis decomposes a treatment‚Äôs effect into: - Direct Effect: The effect of treatment not through the mediator - Indirect Effect: The effect of treatment through a mediator variable

1. üß™ Simulate Mediated Effects 

set.seed(123)
n <- 1000

X <- rbinom(n, 1, 0.5)                # treatment
M <- 1.2 * X + rnorm(n)               # mediator
Y <- 0.5 * X + 2 * M + rnorm(n)       # outcome influenced by both

df <- data.frame(X, M, Y)

2. üßÆ Fit Models for Mediation Analysis 

# Mediator model
model_M <- lm(M ~ X, data = df)

# Outcome model including mediator
model_Y <- lm(Y ~ X + M, data = df)

3. üîç Estimate Mediation Effects 

med <- mediate(model_M, model_Y, treat = "X", mediator = "M", boot = TRUE, sims = 500)
summary(med)
## 
## Causal Mediation Analysis 
## 
## Nonparametric Bootstrap Confidence Intervals with the Percentile Method
## 
##                Estimate 95% CI Lower 95% CI Upper p-value    
## ACME              2.479        2.231         2.78  <2e-16 ***
## ADE               0.370        0.235         0.50  <2e-16 ***
## Total Effect      2.849        2.579         3.15  <2e-16 ***
## Prop. Mediated    0.870        0.827         0.92  <2e-16 ***
## ---
## Signif. codes:  0 '***' 0.001 '**' 0.01 '*' 0.05 '.' 0.1 ' ' 1
## 
## Sample Size Used: 1000 
## 
## 
## Simulations: 500

4. üìä Visualize Mediation Summary 

plot(med)

‚úÖ Interpretation

  • ACME: Average causal mediation effect (indirect effect)
  • ADE: Average direct effect
  • Total Effect: ACME + ADE
  • Proportion Mediated: Fraction of total effect due to mediation

üìñ References

  • Imai, Keele, Tingley (2010). A general approach to causal mediation analysis
  • Pearl (2001). Direct and indirect effects
